title: Boris opens Super Saturday by telling MPs to ‘come together’ over Brexit deal
text:
Boris Johnson is trying to pass his deal in the House of Commons today (Picture: PA)

Boris Johnson has made a last-minute plea to MPs to pass his new Brexit deal during a historic House of Commons sitting.

The PM said that ‘now is the time’ for politicians to come together and end the impasse surrounding our exit from the EU.

He said his new deal had the ability to ‘heal the country’ noting that the issue of Brexit had divided not only Parliament but also friends, family and neighbours.

Mr Johnson declared he had secured a ‘new and better deal for the UK’ which would restore sovereignty and free the nation from EU rules and regulations.

He said the agreement would allow the UK to leave ‘entire and whole’ on October 31.

Addressing politicians, he said: ‘The House will need no reminding that this is the second deal and the fourth vote, three-and-a-half years after the nation voted for Brexit.

‘And during those years friendships have been strained, families divided and the attention of this House consumed by a single issue that has at times felt incapable of resolution.

‘But I hope that this is the moment when we can finally achieve that resolution and reconcile the instincts that compete within us.’

Speaker of the House of Commons John Bercow officiates over the debate (Picture: AFP)

The Tory leader is facing race to secure a majority in the House of Commons with political experts saying the vote is ‘too close to call.’

He needs 320 votes for his new bill to pass, paving the way for an exit in less than two weeks.

Mr Johnson’s former DUP allies have vowed to vote against him as have all the opposition groups.

This means the PM is relying on the support of a handful of Labour rebels and the Tories he sacked last month.

Mr Johnson added: ‘Now is the time for this great House of Commons to come together and bring this country together today as I believe people at home are hoping and expecting.’

Mr Johnson addresses a full House of Commons (Picture: EPA)

Labour’s Jeremy Corbyn said the new deal, agreed with the EU on Thursday, was a ‘sell-out.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

He said it would result in a ‘race to the bottom in regulation and standards’ as we are no longer bound to guarantees on workers’ rights and environmental protections.

He urged for it to be voted down, saying ‘this Government can’t be trusted and these benches will not be duped’.

He added: ‘It is not a good deal for our country and future generations who will feel the impact. It should be voted down.

‘I totally understand the frustration and the fatigue across the country and in this House.

‘But we simply cannot vote for a deal that is even worse than the one this House rejected three times.’

If the deal does not pass through the House of Commons, the Benn Act kicks in which would force Mr Johnson to ask the EU for another delay until at least the end of January 2019.

Mr Johnson used his opening speech to rule out asking for an extension saying it would be ‘pointless, expensive and deeply corrosive of public trust.’

All 27 EU members would have to agree to an extension, meaning a no-deal is still possible as it is the default legal setting.

Advertisement

The revised deal is very similar to Theresa May’s thrice-rejected blueprint.

It covers Britain’s financial settlement – around £33 billion – protects the rights of EU citizens and sets out a post EU transition phase likely to last until 2022 while new trade terms can be hammered out.

However it ditches the hated Irish backstop, the measure designed to prevent a return to physical checks on the Irish border.

Instead it will, in effect, draw a new customs border along the Irish Sea as Northern Ireland will still be bound to some EU laws on trade.

This has led to accusations that Mr Johnson has ‘sold out’ Northern Ireland in his hurry to secure an exit and flies in the face of previous promises the PM has given.

Sir Oliver Letwin has tabled an amendment which could see another extension (Picture: AFP)

Today’s Parliamentary session is the first weekend sitting since the invasion of the Falklands in 1982.

Before the main Brexit vote, there will be decisions made on a number of amendments including one tabled by former Tory minister Sir Oliver Letwin, which could derail today’s proceedings.

Advertisement

There are fears that Mr Johnson will still be able to allow the UK to crash out of the bloc if no trade deals are agreed during the two-year transition period.

The Letwin amendment would withhold approval until all the legislation is in place, acting as an ‘insurance policy’ to prevent an ‘accidental no-deal.’

His amendment would automatically trigger the Benn Act, meaning a delay of at least three months.

Government sources have suggested if the Letwin amendment passes then they will simply send the Tory MPs home and the main Brexit vote will not happen.

Mr Johnson held crisis talks with Sir Oliver last night in a bid to head off the crisis, but without success.

Labour has officially backed the amendment and other opposition groups are expected to back it.

Remainers are still pushing for a second referendum and hundreds of thousands of people are expected to head to Westminster for a People’s Vote march later today.
